com.itko.lisa.test

Class TestEventMgr

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisa.test.TestEventMgr

  • public class TestEventMgr
extends java.lang.Object
    A TestEventMgr is a queue for receiving LISA events and publishing those events to interested listeners. There are multiple instances of TestEventMgr queues created during the execution of tests, and each queue will have its own list of listeners to whom it publishes events. Some of these queues subscribe to other TestEventMgr queues to enable events to travel to different components.
    See Also:
    TestEventListener

    • Constructor Detail

      • TestEventMgr

        public TestEventMgr()
        Default constructor

      • TestEventMgr

        public TestEventMgr(java.lang.String owner)
        This constructor allows the caller to identify who created the object; this is only a debugging aid and does not otherwise impact the behavior. A handful of classes create instances of TestEventMgr, so knowing who created the queue is helpful for debugging. For example, the Coordinator names its queue after its own name, so you'll see names like "local" or the actual coordinator name; the SimulatorImpl also names its TestEventMgr after itself.
        Parameters:
        owner -

    • Method Detail

      • getOwner

        public java.lang.String getOwner()
        This identifies the creator of this event queue. Its ONLY purpose is as a debugging aid; the owner is included in log messages to enable the developer to identify which queue is doing what.
        Returns:
        the name of the creator as an assist for log messages

      • addListener

        public void addListener(TestEventListener cl,
               int[] filter)
        This method adds a listener to the collection of listeners.
        Parameters:
        cl - - object that supports the interface to get events
        filter - - the array of Event IDs that you DON'T WANT sent to you quite useful to reduce chatter on the line

        Note that if you want to make sure you get all the events that could possibly be sent, send TestEvent.noFilter as the filter. If you want to get most, but not the painfully bandwidth-hungary ones, send null or TestEvent.defaultFilter.

        See Also:
        contains all the Event IDs so you know what you do/don't want to filter.

      • addListener

        public void addListener(TestEventListener cl,
               int[] filter,
               boolean quietToo)
        This method adds a listener to the collection of listeners. We DO NOT guarantee that only one instance of a TestEventListener in our list. Specifically, if a listener is added twice, it will receive events twice.
        Parameters:
        cl - - object that supports the interface to get events
        filter - - the array of Event IDs that you DON'T WANT sent to you quite useful to reduce chatter on the line
        quietToo - - do you want even events considered quiet (suppressed by the test author)

        Note that if you want to make sure you get all the events that could possibly be sent, send TestEvent.noFilter as the filter. If you want to get most, but not the painfully bandwidth-hungary ones, send null or TestEvent.defaultFilter.

        See Also:
        contains all the Event IDs so you know what you do/don't want to filter.

      • mergeFilterInfoExisting

        public static int[] mergeFilterInfoExisting(int[] efilter,
                            int[] nfilter)
        Use this method when you are trying to merge a new filter (as nfilter) into an existing filter (efilter). Coordinators and reports might have to do this, where based on interactive user input, they might need to update this test event manager after the listener has been registered. Applying the new to the existing means that if an event is NOT filtered in the new filter but is in the existing, we will remove the filter for that event from the existing filter. The idea is that the existing filter needs to a be a superset of the new filter.
        Parameters:
        efilter - - the existing filter to update
        nfilter - - new filter to apply
        Returns:
        the updated filter after the merge

      • filterToStringList

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> filterToStringList(int[] events)

        public static int[] addFilter(int[] efilter,
              int eventId)
        add an event id to an existing filter. if it's already there, leave it alone
        Parameters:
        efilter - existing filter to update
        eventId - new event to filter out
        Returns:
        merged array
